questions.text: Which among the following is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults?
questions.solution:
Malignant melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults.

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.

questions.text: Which is the most common primary malignant tumor of the lid?
questions.solution:
The most common primary malignant tumor of the lid is basal cell carcinoma.

The second most common tumor of the lid is squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common lid malignancy in HIV patients?
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma is the commonest malignancy of the lid and conjunctiva in HIV patients.

It appears as a violaceous non-tender nodule on the eyelid or conjunctiva. It is a rapidly growing acquired neoplasm composed of malignant stromal cells densely vascularized by blood vessels of capillary size.

The typical lesion appears as an expanding, bright red subepithelial mass that projects through and replaces the overlying conjunctival epithelium. Spontaneous bleeding leading to bloody tears or a subconjunctival hematoma is relatively common.

Conjunctival Kaposi’s sarcoma can be treated by excision, cryotherapy, radiation therapy (external beam or contact therapy), chemotherapy, or topical or intralesional interferon-α.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used in the management of the clinical condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a capillary hemangioma involving the left upper lid and periocular area. Interferon beta is not used in the management of capillary hemangioma. However, note that interferon alfa-2a is used in resistant cases.

A capillary haemangioma is the most common tumor of the orbit and periorbital area in childhood.

It may present as small isolated lesions or large masses that can cause visual impairment (due to mechanical ptosis and the resulting sensory deprivation amblyopia), systemic effects (severe thrombocytopenia), or exist as part of PHACE syndrome (Posterior fossa anomalies, Hemangioma, Arterial lesions, Cardiac abnormalities, Eye or Endocrine abnormalities)

30% of lesions resolve by the age of 3 years and about 75% by the age of 7.

Indications for treatment are:

  1. Visual (amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion, strabismus)
  2. Cosmesis
  3. Optic nerve compression
  4. Exposure keratopathy

Treatment options include:

  • Beta blockers- oral propranolol, topical timolol.
  • Steroids- intralesional triamcinolone or betamethasone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids.
  • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine- for steroid-resistant sight-threatening lesions
  • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser.

questions.text: An 8-year old child presented with right-sided proptosis. Biopsy of the orbital mass was done and histopathological examination revealed this picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS). Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. 

40% of rhabdomyosarcomas develop in the head and neck, and they are the most common primary orbital malignancy in children but are still a rare condition. The older age of the child presenting with proptosis suggests rhabdomyosarcoma (average age 7 to 8 years) than retinoblastoma (average age at presentation is 18 months).

The histopathology shows elongated to round spindle cells with features of skeletal muscle at different stages of maturation with highly eosinophilic cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei – the embryonal type of rhabdomyosarcoma

Immunohistochemistry is useful in identifying skeletal muscle proteins, such as alpha-actin, myosin, desmin, and myoglobin

Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and hematogenous and lymphatic metastases.

Decision-making for management is based on histopathologic confirmation as well as the staging of orbital RMS, which includes imaging (MRI of primary tumor, chest-CT, Tc bone scan), pathology, and work-up for metastases(bone marrow biopsy).

Treatment options include chemotherapy (vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and actinomycin D) and radiotherapy.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on angiography?
questions.solution:
The clinical vigenette is of a patient presenting with painless dimunition of vision and metamorphopsia with the right fundus showing choroidal melanoma superotemporal to the optic disc and involving the macula.

In this patient a “Double circulation” pattern consisting of an internal circulation within the lesion and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina will be seen on angiography.

Although collar stud(Option C) appearance is pathagnomic for choroidal melanoma, it can be seen on B-scan and not on angiography. 

Choroidal melanoma is a primary intraocular malignancy in adults that peaks around 60 years of age.

Symptoms include a range of visual disturbances such as painless decrease in vision and metamorphosia when macula is involved.

Other features of Choroidal melanoma includes:

  • A solitary elevated subretinal grey-brown dome shaped mass
  • Clumps of orange pigment are common over the mass
  • Collar stud appearance on B-scan (option C): It is pathagnomic of choridal melanoma. It is seen if the tumour breaks through the Bruch's membrane into the subretinal space .
  • Associated haemorrhage

Smoke stack pattern (option A) and ink blot (option B) pattern is seen on FFA in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

CSR is the spontaneous serous detachment of the sensory neuroretina in the foveal region with or without retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) detachment.

This occurs due Choroidal vascular hyperpermeability.

On FFA it is initially seen as an ink-blot pattern or smoke stack pattern of hyperfluorescence which then spreads to take the configuration of mushroom or umbrella pattern.

The below given images depict the smoke stack pattern and mushroom pattern respectively

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with jaundice. He was recently diagnosed with malignant melanoma of the uvea but did not receive proper treatment due to the prevalent pandemic situation. Investigations reveal liver secondaries. What would be the ideal line of management?
questions.solution:
The spread of malignant melanoma of the uvea outside the orbit is treated with enucleation + chemotherapy + immunotherapy.

Orbital spread of the malignant melanoma necessitates exenteration but metastasis elsewhere can be treated by enucleation, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy.

questions.text: A father has noticed that his child's left pupil appears white as shown below. Worried about this, the father consults an ophthalmologist. All of the following should be included in the differential diagnosis except:
questions.solution:
The child has leukocoria and congenital glaucoma is not to be included in the differential diagnosis.

Various conditions, other than retinoblastoma, which present as leukocoria are collectively called pseudoglioma.

Differential diagnosis of leukocoria:

  1. Retinoblastoma
  2. Congenital cataract
  3. Coloboma of the choroid
  4. Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous
  5. Toxocara infestation
  6. Norrie disease
  7. Coat's exudative retinopathy

Intraocular pressure (IOP) is usually raised in retinoblastoma and lowered in pseudoglioma.

questions.text: Retinoblastoma arises from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma (also called glioma retinae) arises from the neurosensory retina. It is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally.

Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

It is of 4 types:

  1. Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
  2. Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
  3. Mixed type
  4. Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
The most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma is leukocoria plus strabismus.

Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Present within the first two years of life
  • Leukocoria 
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre-septal cellulitis.
  • Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases.
  • Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular involvement is rare.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was brought by his parents with concern about being increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On examination, there is leukocoria with an absence of the red reflex in the left eye. As further workup reveals a tumor, the eye is enucleated and the microscopic appearance is as shown in the image. Molecular analysis of the tumor indicates loss of cell cycle control in the tumor cells. Where is the responsible gene located?
questions.solution:
The histology showing Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and clinical history of white reflex point towards a diagnosis of retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is due to mutation in Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma was first cancer known to be directly associated with a genetic abnormality.

 The HPE image below shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, the clustering of small blue cuboidal or short columnar cells around a central lumen.

questions.text: Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of retinoblastoma.

Knudson's hypothesis can be stated as follows:

  • Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB are required to produce retinoblastoma.
  • In familial retinoblastoma, one of the pair of alleles of RB1 is mutated in all the cells of the body. When a further mutagenic event ("second hit" according to the "two-hit" hypothesis proposed by Knudson) affects the second allele, the cell may then undergo malignant transformation. A large majority of these children develop bilateral and multifocal tumors.
  • In sporadic cases, both RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits).

Familial retinoblastoma patients also have a predisposition to non-ocular cancers because of the presence of the mutation in all cells, such as pinealoblastoma (usually before the age of 5 years), osteosarcomas, soft tissue sarcomas, and melanomas.

Note:

Trilateral retinoblastoma = Pinealoblastoma + Bilateral retinoblastoma

questions.text: Why would an ophthalmologist use the Reese-Ellsworth classification for retinoblastoma?

choices.text: For the management of the tumor
For the staging of the tumor
For the assessment of the survival of the eye after local therapy
For the assessment of the survival of the patient after surgery

questions.solution:
Reese–Ellsworth classification is used in predicting which eye would survive the local therapy (cryotherapy, photocoagulation, plaque radiation therapy) and retain useful vision.

Cryotherapy is used for retinoblastoma lesions anterior to the equator and photocoagulation for lesions posterior to the equator.

Group Prognosis for maintenance of sight Features
1 Very favorable
  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all <4DD, all at or behind the equator
2 Favorable
  • Solitary tumor, 4–10 DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all 4–10DD all behind the equator
3 Possible
  • Any lesion anterior to the equator
  • Solitary tumor, >10DD behind the equator
4 Unfavorable
  • Multiple tumors, some >10 DD
  • Any lesion extending anteriorly to ora serrata
5 Highly unfavorable
  • Massive tumors involving more than one half of the retina
  • Vitreous seeding

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy who presented with strabismus and leukocoria is suspected to have retinoblastoma. A B-scan detects multiple endophytic masses with calcifications, the largest measuring 6DD, and the smallest measuring 4 DD. CT scan reveals intraocular foci of calcifications and no other anomaly. The ophthalmologist decides to use chemo-reduction and local therapy to treat this child. According to Reese-Ellsworth classification, this belongs to which group?
questions.solution:
Multiple tumors of 4-10 DD in size behind the equator belong to group 2.

Group Prognosis for maintenance of sight Features
1 Very favorable
  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all <4DD, all at or behind the equator
2 Favorable
  • Solitary tumor, 4–10 DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all 4–10DD all behind the equator
3 Possible
  • Any lesion anterior to equator
  • Solitary tumor, >10DD behind equator
4 Unfavorable
  • Multiple tumors, some >10 DD
  • Any lesion extending anteriorly to ora serrata
5 Highly unfavorable
  • Massive tumors involving more than one half of the retina
  • Vitreous seeding

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice when retinoblastoma involves the optic nerve?
questions.solution:
Optic nerve involvement is treated by enucleation + adjuvant chemotherapy + radiotherapy

Indications for enucleation [Group E tumor - according to the International Classification of Retinoblastoma (ICRB)]:

  • Tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • Optic nerve involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

questions.text: Which of the following regimen is commonly usedâ€‹ in the treatment of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution: Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for anterior lesions of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Cryotherapy is used for anterior lesions of retinoblastoma.

Photocoagulation for posterior lesions of retinoblastoma.

questions.text: The most common secondaries in choroid are from _____.
questions.solution:
The most common secondaries in choroid originate from the breast (overall and in females), and lungs (in males).

Examination shows the elevation of the retina, usually at the posterior pole. It is usually bilateral.

Metastases are usually treated with systemic chemotherapy and immunotherapy. Radiotherapy may also be given.
